query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 S’ïo avessi le rime aspre e chiocce, 2 come si converrebbe al tristo buco 3 sovra ’l qual pontan tutte l’altre rocce,
4 io premerei di mio concetto il suco 5 più pienamente; ma perch’ io non l’abbo, 6 non sanza tema a dicer mi conduco;
7 ché non è impresa da pigliare a gabbo 8 discriver fondo a tutto l’universo, 9 né da lingua che chiami mamma o babbo.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Ma quelle donne aiutino il mio verso 11 ch’aiutaro Anfïone a chiuder Tebe, 12 sì che dal fatto il dir non sia diverso.
query.result: **English:**10 But may those ladies help my verse, 11 who helped Amphion to enclose Thebes, 12 so that the telling may not be different from the deed.**Cornish:**10 Mesaga'n benenes re beu'm gerens, 11 a skoedhas Amphion dhe golghi Theb, 12 rag dhyworth an gwrians na vo gwrys an ober.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Oh sovra tutte mal creata plebe 14 che stai nel loco onde parlare è duro, 15 mei foste state qui pecore o zebe!
16 Come noi fummo giù nel pozzo scuro 17 sotto i piè del gigante assai più bassi, 18 e io mirava ancora a l’alto muro,
19 dicere udi’mi: «Guarda come passi: 20 va sì, che tu non calchi con le piante 21 le teste de’ fratei miseri lassi».
query.result:
**English:**
13 Oh, above all, wretchedly created rabble, 14 who are in the place where it is hard to speak, 15 may you have been sheep or goats here!
16 As we were down in the dark pit, 17 far below the giant’s feet, 18 and I was still looking up at the high wall,
19 I heard someone say to me: “Watch how you step: 20 go so that you do not tread with your feet 21 on the heads of your wretched, weary brothers.”
**Cornish:**
13 Oh, a-ugh dhe bub, pleb anfurvys, 14 ow th’y’th yn le unn le mayth kovsoweth, 15 my a veth ev owth peth ow zeb!
16 Avel mayth owth yn-nans an pow sordh, 17 a-ugh dhe ves an gew orth ughella, 18 ha my a welas dhe voya ughella,
19 kovsoweth owth dhe “Gwel marth owth pass: 20 kov mayth, mar nas owth camm orth dha ves 21 dhe bennow an dha vreuderow trist.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Per ch’io mi volsi, e vidimi davante 23 e sotto i piedi un lago che per gelo 24 avea di vetro e non d’acqua sembiante.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Therefore I turned and saw before me 23 and beneath my feet a lake that, because of the ice, 24 seemed to be of glass and not of water.
**Cornish:**
22 Rag henna'm troas ha'm gwelas ow kledhes 23 ha danow tra'm treus lyn a'gawra, drehevys 24 avel gwydr ha na dhowr yth esa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Non fece al corso suo sì grosso velo 26 di verno la Danoia in Osterlicchi, 27 né Tanaï là sotto ’l freddo cielo,
28 com’ era quivi; che se Tambernicchi 29 vi fosse sù caduto, o Pietrapana, 30 non avria pur da l’orlo fatto cricchi.
query.result:
**English:**
25 The Danube in Austria did not make so thick a veil 26 of ice over its course in winter, 27 nor the Don under the cold sky,
28 as was there; for if Mount Tambura 29 or Mount Pietrapana had fallen on it, 30 it would not have made a crack at the edge.
**Cornish:**
25 Nyns yw gwella’y avon war an norvys 26 Danow yn Osterlicchi, 27 na Tanaï dan an ebron sel,
28 ages ovel a hemma; rag gemmyn Tambernicchi 29 po Pietrapana a veusist kewsys war’n-y, 30 ny veusist gwres oll mes un krik war y bord.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 E come a gracidar si sta la rana 32 col muso fuor de l’acqua, quando sogna 33 di spigolar sovente la villana,
34 livide, insin là dove appar vergogna 35 eran l’ombre dolenti ne la ghiaccia, 36 mettendo i denti in nota di cicogna.
query.result:
**English:**
31 And as the frog sits croaking 32 with its snout out of the water, when the peasant woman dreams 33 of gathering ears of corn,
34 livid, up to where shame appears, 35 were the sorrowful shades in the ice, 36 chattering their teeth like storks.
**Cornish:**
31 Ha kepar ha bos ogas an ranon 32 gans y fri yn-mes an dowr, pan yw hi ow sonja 33 a-gas spigla an vilones,
34 liv, bys dhe’n le mayth an gonar, 35 ovel an scouthow trist y’n an jea, 36 ow tos ow dens kepar noten an sigon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Ognuna in giù tenea volta la faccia; 38 da bocca il freddo, e da li occhi il cor tristo 39 tra lor testimonianza si procaccia.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Each one kept its face turned downward; 38 the cold from their mouths and the sorrow from their eyes 39 bore witness to each other.
**Cornish:**
37 Pep onan o jallen y honen y fas; 38 an jea ow tos ow frig, ha’n gonar an trist 39 a wra gweles an eyl y gila.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Quand’ io m’ebbi dintorno alquanto visto, 41 volsimi a’ piedi, e vidi due sì stretti, 42 che ’l pel del capo avieno insieme misto.
query.result:
**English:**
40 When I had looked around me for a while, 41 I turned to my feet and saw two so close together, 42 that the hair on their heads was mingled.
**Cornish:**
40 Pan o jallen ow tos ow gweles a-dro, 41 y troas ow tra’m treus, ha’m gwelas dew a veu 42 ow tos ow blew an pennow kemmyskys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 «Ditemi, voi che sì strignete i petti», 44 diss’ io, «chi siete?». E quei piegaro i colli; 45 e poi ch’ebber li visi a me eretti,
46 li occhi lor, ch’eran pria pur dentro molli, 47 gocciar su per le labbra, e ’l gelo strinse 48 le lagrime tra essi e riserrolli.
query.result:
**English:**
43 "Tell me, you who press your chests so close together," 44 I said, "who are you?" And they bowed their heads; 45 and after they had raised their faces to me,
46 their eyes, which were once soft within, 47 dripped down over their lips, and the frost tightened 48 the tears between them and sealed them shut.
**Cornish:**
43 "Leverel vy, neb a strig ow bledhys kemmyskys", 44 owth owth, "piw yw hy?" Ha henna a blygas ow fenow; 45 ha wosa wosa ow tos ow honys ow sevel dhe’m,
46 ow lagha, a veu unwaith melyon a-ji, 47 a dhillas war-tu ow lipa, ha’n jea a wrigas 48 an degerow ynter aga ha’n serras.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Con legno legno spranga mai non cinse 50 forte così; ond’ ei come due becchi 51 cozzaro insieme, tanta ira li vinse.
query.result:
**English:**
49 Never did iron fetter bind wood to wood 50 so tightly; therefore, like two goats, 51 they clashed together, so much anger overcame them.
**Cornish:**
49 Nyns yw pren pren ow spryngya erer 50 kemmyskys kalet; rag henna kepar dew vohk 51 a gosas owth, kemmyskys o jallas ow has.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 E un ch’avea perduti ambo li orecchi 53 per la freddura, pur col viso in giùe, 54 disse: «Perché cotanto in noi ti specchi?
55 Se vuoi saper chi son cotesti due, 56 la valle onde Bisenzo si dichina 57 del padre loro Alberto e di lor fue.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And one who had lost both his ears 53 to the cold, with his face still down, 54 said: "Why do you gaze at us so intently?
55 If you want to know who these two are, 56 the valley from which the Bisenzio flows down 57 was their father Alberto's and theirs.
**Cornish:**
52 Ha onan a veu kollet y dewlagas 53 drehevys an jea, gans y fas ow tos a-ji, 54 a leveris: "Rag henna ow tos ow spekjya kemmyskys dhe’n-agan?
55 Mar mynnys gweles piw a-dro an dew, 56 an glyn le mayth Bisenzo a dhillas 57 o veu Alberto ow tas ha henna."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 D’un corpo usciro; e tutta la Caina 59 potrai cercare, e non troverai ombra 60 degna più d’esser fitta in gelatina:
61 non quelli a cui fu rotto il petto e l’ombra 62 con esso un colpo per la man d’Artù; 63 non Focaccia; non questi che m’ingombra
64 col capo sì, ch’i’ non veggio oltre più, 65 e fu nomato Sassol Mascheroni; 66 se tosco se’, ben sai omai chi fu.
query.result:
**English:**
58 They came from one body; and throughout all of Caina 59 you could search and not find a shade 60 more deserving of being stuck in jelly:
61 not those whose chests and shadows were pierced 62 with one blow by Arthur's hand; 63 not Focaccia; not this one who blocks my view
64 with his head, so that I can see no further, 65 and who was named Sassol Mascheroni; 66 if you are Tuscan, you now know well who he was.
**Cornish:**
58 A onan korf yth ethens; ha dreus oll Caina 59 y hallerth gweles, ha ny gevys owth 60 ow tos ow teves dhe vos yn jelatina:
61 Nyns henna re beu a veu y brust ha’n ebron 62 ow tos ow kollet gans onan tas dre le Artù; 63 Nyns Focaccia; nyns henna a wra ow ingombra
64 gans y ben ow tos owth owth ow gweles pella, 65 ha y hanow o veu Sassol Mascheroni; 66 Mar tuskan yw hy, owth owth ow tos owth ef.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 E perché non mi metti in più sermoni, 68 sappi ch’i’ fu’ il Camiscion de’ Pazzi; 69 e aspetto Carlin che mi scagioni».
query.result:
**English:**
67 And so that you do not engage me in further conversation, 68 know that I was Camicion de' Pazzi; 69 and I await Carlino to exonerate me."
**Cornish:**
67 Ha rag na wra hy ow pos ow sermoni pella, 68 gowth owth ow jallen Camiscion de’ Pazzi; 69 ha owth ow tos ow Carlin rag ow skwyson owth."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Poscia vid’ io mille visi cagnazzi 71 fatti per freddo; onde mi vien riprezzo, 72 e verrà sempre, de’ gelati guazzi.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Then I saw a thousand snarling faces, 71 made hideous by the cold; from which I still shudder, 72 and always will, at the thought of those icy pools.
**Cornish:**
70 Wosa henna my a welas mil vis cagnazzi 71 gwres gans oergans; drefen a dheuth dhemm, 72 ha dheuth byth, a'n poosow gelys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Piangendo mi sgridò: «Perché mi peste? 80 se tu non vieni a crescer la vendetta 81 di Montaperti, perché mi moleste?».
query.result:
**English:**
79 Weeping, he cried out to me: "Why do you trample on me? 80 If you do not come to avenge the defeat 81 of Montaperti, why do you torment me?".**Cornish:**
79 Yn kegy, ev a leveris dhym: "Perak rag om pys?" 80 Mar ny wra vy dhe wul dhe venjans 81 a Vontaperti, perak rag om pys?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 E io: «Maestro mio, or qui m’aspetta, 83 sì ch’io esca d’un dubbio per costui; 84 poi mi farai, quantunque vorrai, fretta».
query.result:
**English:**
82 And I: "Master, now wait for me here, 83 so that I may escape from a doubt because of him; 84 then you may hurry me, as much as you wish".**Cornish:**
82 Ha my: "Mester vy, wosa omma a-wul, 83 rag om a-dhia a-dhymm dhe-worth rag an prysoner; 84 wosa omma a-wra dhe-worth, pyth vy a-vynn".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Lo duca stette, e io dissi a colui 86 che bestemmiava duramente ancora: 87 «Qual se’ tu che così rampogni altrui?».
query.result:
**English:**
85 The leader stopped, and I said to the one 86 who was still blaspheming harshly: 87 "Who are you that so revile others?".**Cornish:**
85 An dyghow a-sevas, ha my a leveris dhe'n prysoner 86 o-vedha blasfema yn kalessa: 87 "Pyth os ty dhe-worth a-lever dres oll?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 «Or tu chi se’ che vai per l’Antenora, 89 percotendo», rispuose, «altrui le gote, 90 sì che, se fossi vivo, troppo fora?».
query.result:
**English:**
88 "Now who are you who go through Antenora, 89 striking others on the cheek", he replied, 90 "so that, if you were alive, it would be too much?".**Cornish:**
88 "Wosa os ty dhe-worth a-dhrehedh dhyworth an Antenora, 89 ow kul dhe-worth dhe'n golgow, 90 mar vyth byw vyw, marow vyth henna?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 «Vivo son io, e caro esser ti puote», 92 fu mia risposta, «se dimandi fama, 93 ch’io metta il nome tuo tra l’altre note».
query.result:
**English:**
91 "I am alive, and it could be dear to you", 92 was my reply, "if you ask for fame, 93 that I may place your name among the other notes".**Cornish:**
91 "Byw vyw ow, ha ker vyth dhe-werth dhe'th gar", 92 o-leveris vy, "mar omma a-houl brys, 93 rag om a-rosa dhe hanow vyw ynter an erel noten".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Ed elli a me: «Del contrario ho io brama. 95 Lèvati quinci e non mi dar più lagna, 96 ché mal sai lusingar per questa lama!».
query.result:
**English:**
94 And he to me: "I have a desire for the opposite. 95 Get away from here and do not bother me anymore, 96 for you know ill how to flatter through this slime!".**Cornish:**
94 Ha henna dhe'm leveris: "An erel a-vynn vyw. 95 Kemer dhyworth omma ha na wra dhe-worth dhe-worth lagna, 96 rag ny wodh vyw pyth dhe-worth dhe-lewya dhyworth an lama!".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Allor lo presi per la cuticagna 98 e dissi: «El converrà che tu ti nomi, 99 o che capel qui sù non ti rimagna».
query.result:
**English:**
97 Then I seized him by the scruff of the neck 98 and said: "You will have to tell me your name, 99 or no hair will remain on your head".**Cornish:**
97 Wosa henna om a-gemeras ev dhe'n golgow 98 ha leveris: "Ev a-wra dhe-worth dhe hanow vyw, 99 po ny wra dhe-worth blew vyw omma".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Ond’ elli a me: «Perché tu mi dischiomi, 101 né ti dirò ch’io sia, né mosterrolti, 102 se mille fiate in sul capo mi tomi».
query.result:
**English:**
100 Whereupon he said to me: "Why do you tear my hair out, 101 nor will I tell you who I am, nor will I show you my face, 102 even if you strike me on the head a thousand times".**Cornish:**
100 Wosa henna ev a leveris dhe'm: "Perak rag om a-dhiskwulma vyw, 101 ha ny wra vyw dhe'th pyth vyw yw, na'ga wra vyw dhe'th dhe-worth dhe hanow vyw, 102 mar omma a-toma vyw war vyw dhe'n ben mil fordh?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Io avea già i capelli in mano avvolti, 104 e tratti glien’ avea più d’una ciocca, 105 latrando lui con li occhi in giù raccolti,
106 quando un altro gridò: «Che hai tu, Bocca? 107 non ti basta sonar con le mascelle, 108 se tu non latri? qual diavol ti tocca?».
query.result:
**English:**
103 I already had his hair wrapped in my hand, 104 and I had pulled out more than one lock, 105 while he snarled at me with his eyes downcast,
106 when another one shouted: "What's the matter with you, Bocca? 107 Isn't it enough for you to clack your jaws, 108 without barking too? What devil is tormenting you?".**Cornish:**
103 O-vedha vyw dhe'n blew ev yn vy skorn, 104 ha om a-dhrosa moy a-dhymm dhe-worth, 105 ow ev ow latra dhe'm gans golgow,
106 pan esel erel a leveris: "Pyth yw dhe-worth, Bocca? 107 Ny yw henna dhe-worth dhe-dhona gans dhe'th gavlow, 108 mar ny wra vyw dhe-worth dhe latra? Pyth dhe-worth an jowl yw dhe-worth dhe-bost?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 «Omai», diss’ io, «non vo’ che più favelle, 110 malvagio traditor; ch’a la tua onta 111 io porterò di te vere novelle».
query.result:
**English:**
109 "Now", I said, "I don't want you to speak any more, 110 evil traitor; for to your shame 111 I will carry true news of you".**Cornish:**
109 "Wosa omma", leveris vyw, "ny vynn vyw dhe'th leverel moy, 110 an jowl bras, rag dhe'th onta 111 vyw a-borta nowethow gwir a-dhyth".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 «Va via», rispuose, «e ciò che tu vuoi conta; 113 ma non tacer, se tu di qua entro eschi, 114 di quel ch’ebbe or così la lingua pronta.
query.result:
**English:**
112 "Go away," he replied, "and tell what you wish; 113 but do not be silent, if you escape from here, 114 about what made his tongue so ready just now."
**Cornish:**
112 "Ke," a leveris, "hagas ha'th owth a vynna; 113 mes na wra vew, mar thu a-dhia owma, 114 a-dro dhe'th ow thas yeth ow thavon bys."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 El piange qui l’argento de’ Franceschi: 116 “Io vidi”, potrai dir, “quel da Duera 117 là dove i peccatori stanno freschi”.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Here he weeps for the silver of the French: 116 "I saw," you will be able to say, "that one from Duera 117 where the sinners are kept cool."
**Cornish:**
115 Ama onan ev a-wela arghans an Frynkis: 116 "Me a welas," a wra'th ow leverel, "an onan a Duera 117 le mayth an pechoryon ow pokoes fres."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Se fossi domandato “Altri chi v’era?”, 119 tu hai dallato quel di Beccheria 120 di cui segò Fiorenza la gorgiera.
query.result:
**English:**
118 If you were asked, "Who else was there?", 119 you have at your side the one from Beccheria, 120 whose throat Florence cut.
**Cornish:**
118 Mar a vydh govynnys "Piv era erel?", 119 tys owth dhe'th ladow an onan a Veccheria 120 a dhreghas Florens y wolgow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Gianni de’ Soldanier credo che sia 122 più là con Ganellone e Tebaldello, 123 ch’aprì Faenza quando si dormia».
query.result:
**English:**
121 I believe that Gianni de’ Soldanier is 122 over there with Ganelon and Tebaldello, 123 who opened Faenza while everyone was asleep.
**Cornish:**
121 Kredys yw Geni de' Soldanier yw 122 moyha pella gans Ganellon ha Tebaldello, 123 a agoras Faenza pan oedh den floghys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Noi eravam partiti già da ello, 125 ch’io vidi due ghiacciati in una buca, 126 sì che l’un capo a l’altro era cappello;
127 e come ’l pan per fame si manduca, 128 così ’l sovran li denti a l’altro pose 129 là ’ve ’l cervel s’aggiugne con la nuca:
130 non altrimenti Tidëo si rose 131 le tempie a Menalippo per disdegno, 132 che quei faceva il teschio e l’altre cose.
query.result:
**English:**
124 We had already left him, 125 when I saw two frozen in one hole, 126 so that one head was a hat for the other;
127 and as bread is eaten out of hunger, 128 so the top one sank his teeth into the other 129 where the brain joins the nape of the neck:
130 Tydeus did not gnaw the temples of Menalippus 131 out of disdain any differently 132 than that one was gnawing the skull and the other parts.
**Cornish:**
124 Ni oedhma parti ow syns, 125 pan welas my dhewdh rewydh yn unn prysk, 126 yn keth onan ben oedh kappel dhe'n aral;
127 ha kepar ha bos marow a vydh kewsys, 128 keth an onan ughella y dhewdh dhe'n aral 129 le mayth an ympynny an ben gans an wolgow:
130 nyns yw Tidëo a rosas an templyow 131 a Menalippo marow gans disdegn, 132 ages an onan ughella an kledha ha'n tra traow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 «O tu che mostri per sì bestial segno 134 odio sovra colui che tu ti mangi, 135 dimmi ’l perché», diss’ io, «per tal convegno,
136 che se tu a ragion di lui ti piangi, 137 sappiendo chi voi siete e la sua pecca, 138 nel mondo suso ancora io te ne cangi,
139 se quella con ch’io parlo non si secca».
query.result:
**English:**
133 "O you who show such a beastly sign 134 of hatred toward the one you are eating, 135 tell me the reason," I said, "by such an agreement,
136 that if you have just cause to weep for him, 137 knowing who you are and his sin, 138 I will still change your story in the world above,
139 if the tongue with which I speak does not dry up."
**Cornish:**
133 "O thus ow a wra'th marow gans keth merk bestial 134 kas ha'n onan owth a dhebrys, 135 leverel dhe'm, 'rag termyn keth," me a leveris,
136 mar thus owth a resen dhe'n ef a-wela, 137 ow kowsos piv thus ow ha'n tra ha'n pekka, 138 yn an bys ughella vyth a wra'th ow chanjya,
139 mar an onan owth ow kovsow nyns yw segh."
